articles.headline: Newsweek on Block as Era of the Newsweekly Fades
articles.snippet: The sale raises questions on whether a fragmented nation still looks to magazines to define the weekly conversation.
articles.abstract: The sale raises questions on whether a fragmented nation still looks to magazines to define the weekly conversation.
articles.lead_paragraph: For generations, Time and Newsweek fought to define the national news agenda every Monday on the newsstand. Before the Internet, before cable news, before People magazine, what the newsweeklies put on their covers mattered.

articles.headline: Back on the Road, but on a Shoestring
articles.snippet: Use a friend’s home instead of a hotel? Drive instead of fly? Videoconference or meet face to face? Business travel is on the mend, but executives are keeping a sharp eye on costs.
articles.abstract: Use a friend’s home instead of a hotel? Drive instead of fly? Videoconference or meet face to face? Business travel is on the mend, but executives are keeping a sharp eye on costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUSINESS travel has often been depicted with a dash of style and adventure. Think of Eva Marie Saint in “North by Northwest,” the various James Bond movies, or George Clooney in “Up in the Air.”

articles.headline: Food to Grab and Go, With Flair
articles.snippet: Short of time and on a budget, many business travelers are bypassing the hotel dining room and even room service. So many hotels are adding quick, lower-cost fare.
articles.abstract: Short of time and on a budget, many business travelers are bypassing the hotel dining room and even room service. So many hotels are adding quick, lower-cost fare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH a Javits Center trade show scheduled to take up the majority of his day last month, Allen Marko, director of technical and plant operations for Obagi Medical Products, had no time to stop for a bite.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Push to Regulate Broadband Is Expected
articles.snippet: The rules ensure the government has authority to move ahead with a sweeping plan to bring high-speed connections to all Americans.
articles.abstract: The rules ensure the government has authority to move ahead with a sweeping plan to bring high-speed connections to all Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission will try to regulate broadband Internet service despite a recent court ruling that the commission had limited powers to do so.

articles.headline: Here’s the Dash... Hold On, What’s a Dash?
articles.snippet: Sony presents a souped-up version of the Chumby, a gadget that scrolls through Internet widgets all day.
articles.abstract: Sony presents a souped-up version of the Chumby, a gadget that scrolls through Internet widgets all day.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the barrage of advertising should make quite clear, the new Sony Dash is here.

articles.headline: Facebook Glitch Brings New Privacy Worries
articles.snippet: A major security flaw in Facebook’s privacy settings heightened a feeling among many users that it was becoming hard to trust the service to protect their personal information.
articles.abstract: A major security flaw in Facebook’s privacy settings heightened a feeling among many users that it was becoming hard to trust the service to protect their personal information.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many users of Facebook, the world’s largest social network, it was just the latest in a string of frustrations.

articles.headline: Bold Stroke May Be Beyond Europe’s Means
articles.snippet: The European Union and the I.M.F. have yet to show the flexibility, political courage and teamwork needed to solve its debt crisis.
articles.abstract: The European Union and the I.M.F. have yet to show the flexibility, political courage and teamwork needed to solve its debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe may need a broad cure to its debt crisis, but the increasingly awkward pairing of the European Union and the International Monetary Fund makes such action unlikely.

articles.headline: As Britain Votes, Economic Clouds Hover
articles.snippet: With government deficits a rising concern, whoever wins the general election will be forced to make deep and unpopular cuts.
articles.abstract: With government deficits a rising concern, whoever wins the general election will be forced to make deep and unpopular cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even with rioters on the streets of Athens and the 16 countries using the euro threatened with mounting turmoil, the economy remained the most frequently — and least candidly — discussed topic here as the three main parties entered the last hours of a monthlong general election campaign.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Teenage Insults, Scrawled on Web, Not on Walls
articles.snippet: A relatively new social networking site has become a magnet for comments, many of them nasty and sexual.
articles.abstract: A relatively new social networking site has become a magnet for comments, many of them nasty and sexual.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the online version of the bathroom wall in school, the place to scrawl raw, anonymous gossip.

articles.headline: Cardinal Has a Mixed Record on Sexual Abuse Cases
articles.snippet: The record of Cardinal William J. Levada, whose Vatican office oversees abuse cases, shows that he often did not act as assertively as he could have.
articles.abstract: The record of Cardinal William J. Levada, whose Vatican office oversees abuse cases, shows that he often did not act as assertively as he could have.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January 2006, Cardinal William J. Levada, the highest ranking American official in the Vatican, slipped into a San Francisco office building, sidestepping a gaggle of media lying in wait. On leave from Rome, he was submitting to a day of questioning before a flotilla of plaintiffs’ lawyers.

articles.headline: Penny Stock Finds Itself in a Corner
articles.snippet: In civil fraud suits filed on Wednesday, the company was charged with falsifying its financial reports and selling shares of nonexistent stock.
articles.abstract: In civil fraud suits filed on Wednesday, the company was charged with falsifying its financial reports and selling shares of nonexistent stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department know what they are talking about, then Steven Y. Moskowitz is a very good liar.

articles.headline: Canada’s Doubts on Toyota
articles.snippet: Newly released documents show that some Canadian regulators were just as frustrated by Toyota as were transportation officials in the United States.
articles.abstract: Newly released documents show that some Canadian regulators were just as frustrated by Toyota as were transportation officials in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — During much of the eight-month crisis between Toyota and safety regulators over recalled vehicles in the United States and Canada, the public pronouncements from the two governments have been remarkably different.

articles.headline: British Voters Swing to Tories, but Majority Is in Doubt
articles.snippet: As Conservatives made big but not necessarily decisive gains, the country could be heading for days of agonizing uncertainty as the two main parties maneuver for power.
articles.abstract: As Conservatives made big but not necessarily decisive gains, the country could be heading for days of agonizing uncertainty as the two main parties maneuver for power.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After one of the most passionately contested elections in decades, the Conservative Party was headed toward big, though not necessarily decisive, gains in Britain early on Friday.

articles.headline: U.S. Markets Plunge, Then Stage a Rebound
articles.snippet: Investigators are examining “unusual trading activity” that may have contributed to the market gyrations.
articles.abstract: Investigators are examining “unusual trading activity” that may have contributed to the market gyrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bad day in the stock market turned into one of the most terrifying moments in Wall Street history on Thursday with a brief 1,000-point plunge that recalled the panic of 2008.
